thread.title: Winnipeg Jets eager to see what they can do on home ice | Hockey | Sports | Toro
thread.title_full: Winnipeg Jets eager to see what they can do on home ice | Hockey | Sports | Toro

author: torontosun.com
title: Winnipeg Jets eager to see what they can do on home ice | Hockey | Sports | Toro
text:
They’re the last team in the NHL to crack open the seal on a new season at home.
They’re also one of the NHL’s surprises, after winning three of four on the road and scoring more goals (15, along with Ottawa) than anybody, going into Thursday night.
The high-flying Winnipeg Jets touch down here, Friday, having learned from last year’s lousy start that points in October are as critical as those in March.
They’re learning something else, too: how to deal with a little more sizzle in the lineup.
The immediate payoff from an injection of skill — hello, Nikolaj Ehlers and Nic Petan — has been the most pleasant surprise for head coach Paul Maurice.
“Some of the creativity, how we moved the puck,” Maurice explained. “We played very poorly on the Island but there was still a feeling we could tie this game up. Didn’t have that sense a lot on the bench last year.
“I knew they would scratch and claw right to the bitter end. But it was a bitter end if we didn’t have the lead a lot of those nights.”
If early-season production from Ehlers and Petan wasn’t completely expected, then neither was the explosive start by Mark Scheifele, not known for busting out of the gate.
Scheifele flashes a brief smile when asked about his three goals, but really gets going when talking about the kids.
“The skill they have is pretty unbelievable,” Scheifele said. “It’s pretty sweet to play with those guys.”
You wonder if Scheifele sees a bit of himself in the rookies. After all, it wasn’t long ago he was dealing with the same things, a skilled player adjusting to a man’s game in a boy’s body and with a boy’s mind.
See the similarities from two years ago?
“Just about everything,” Scheifele agreed. “It’s tough coming in as a young guy and trying to make an impression. Trying to play your way and mix it with the way the team plays. You’ve got a lot of emotions, a lot of everything — buddies talking to you about the play you made the night before.
“But they’re pretty mature guys.”
Scheifele says he tries to help, and the kids could do worse than follow his lead.
Initially unable to produce, No. 55 worked hard on the lesser-known points of the game — the defensive responsibility, the positioning, faceoffs — while waiting for the offence to come.
But he’d rather talk about watching the rookies grow.
“Especially Nik Ehlers ... it’s pretty cool — I see things that he goes through and I’m like, ‘Man, I literally went through the exact same thing.’ ”
Leading the way, though, is still the “old guard” — Blake Wheeler’s five points, Mark Stuart’s plus-6 (along with Jacob Trouba) and Dustin Byfuglien’s three penalties.
OK, maybe that last one isn’t an example to follow.
“We had a chat about that,” Maurice said of the team’s penchant for being in the box. “I’m surprised at the number, to be honest. I can live with the penalties we took against the Rangers. Because they were part of a compete package that is who we are as a team. The penalties we took against the Islanders were not acceptable.”
The penalties are a continuation of last season.
I guess you can’t learn everything in one year.
“That’s almost expected now,” Wheeler said, chuckling. “I don’t know. We scored a shorthanded goal last game so it doesn’t feel like a big issue now.”
Then a sober second thought.
“We’ve got to stay out of the box — that’s obviously a key. We’re aware of it.”
Ask Maurice what’s on top of his fix-it list, and he doesn’t mention penalties, but high-risk plays.
While implementing new concepts to create more offence this season, the boss has seen some unwanted side effects of his bulked-up attack.
“We’re scoring some goals, but we’ve given up two three-on-one goals in the last two games,” Maurice said. “Great players make the risky plays ... if you’re not making them, you’re just a risky player.
“Nobody’s coming off the bench hearing, ‘Dump that puck.’ But we’re going to have to spend the year really defining what a good decision is.”
As for a good season, well, the start doesn’t define that, either.
The Jets learned that last year.
“Nobody’s getting any, ‘Hey we’re 3-1’ tattoos,” Maurice cracked.
Good plan.
Because angst can be just a home opener away.
Winnipeg Jets eager to see what they can do on home ice Maurice: 'Nobody's getting any, 'Hey we're 3-1' tattoos'
By Paul Friesen , Winnipeg Sun First posted: Thursday, October 15, 2015 02:58 PM EDT | Updated: Thursday, October 15, 2015 08:12 PM EDT
The Winnipeg Jets will take a 3-1 record and near-perfect health into their home opener against Calgary, Friday.
Only defenceman Ben Chiarot is expected to miss a second straight game, as the Jets become the last NHL team to play on home ice.
With six straight games here, Winnipeg has a chance to put some points in the bank — if it can quickly establish the identity it wants to have in its own building.
“We didn't do that until March last year,” head coach Paul Maurice said, Thursday. “We were a middling team and we got home and needed to be good, and it became a very good place for us. You can't be bad at home and expect to have a good season.”
Maurice says it's too early to draw too many conclusions about his team.
Asked to name one pleasant surprise, he points to the improved skill level and ability to score. Winnipeg and Ottawa lead the NHL with 15 goals.
